analytic.title: Sparse Representation with Harmonic Wavelets

monogr.title: 2009 Sixth International Conference on Fuzzy Systems and Knowledge Discovery

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: A simple method, based on harmonic wavelets, is proposed for the decomposition of a suitable signal into a periodic function and a pulse. It will be shown that, under some general conditions, by a simple projection into two disjoint orthogonal space of functions the periodic component of the signal can be separated from the localized part. The proposed algorithm, gives an approximate (scale depending) decomposition and can be used also for an efficient denoising (as shown in the final examples).

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The sparse representation of signals (see e.g. [15], [16] and references therein) has been considered as a powerful tool for denoising, coding, compression, source separation [4], [10], [14], [17], [22], [23]. The main idea is to decompose a given signal into a linear combination of functions each of which referring to a suitable basis. In other words, the functional space, taken into consideration, is the span of the union of two family of bases. Usually these bases give some redundant systems unless they are orthogonal each other. The functional space will be given as a direct sum of two orthogonal subspaces having as bases the Fourier harmonic functions and the Littlewood Paley functions respectively. Littlewood Paley functions [11], [12], [18], also called harmonic wavelets [5], [6], [7], [19], [20], [21], despite their low decay in time, have been shown to be a good tool for studying processes which are sharply localized in frequency, as it happens in any kind of signal dealing with highly oscillating systems (vibrations). Harmonic wavelets are a family of basis functions, which enjoy many advantages: a) they are analytically defined and band limited; b) their connections coefficients (refinable integrals) can be easily and finitely computed [5] for any moment (any order derivative); c) the real part of the scaling coefficients are the Shannon wavelets and generalizes the corresponding sampling theorem [6]; d) they can be used to easily represent [8], [9] and analyze self-similar (fractal) signals. It has been shown that wavelets can be a good tool for investigating the main features of fractals [1], [2], [3], [13], [14], [23]. On the other hand, harmonic wavelets have a slow decay in time thus raising some doubts on their usefulness (comparing with other families of wavelets having e.g. the compact support). In the following, it will be shown that harmonic wavelets enjoy also the important property of being orthogonal to the Fourier basis. As a consequence it is possible to decompose the union of periodic functions and localized functions into a direct sum of orthogonal spaces, thus obtaining a sparse representation of the space. The orthogonal decomposition of the space will be applied to some examples of denoising. The next step will be to obtain the sparse representation for discrete sets, but this can be approached and achieved by the discrete harmonic wavelet transform [21].

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In this paper it is given a sparse representation of a noised signal into a periodic part and a pulse (localized in the origin). It has been proven that harmonic wavelets are orthogonal to the Fourier basis, so that a suitable orthogonal decomposition of the space was proposed (even if at a certain scale approximation). However, it should be noticed that the decomposition theorem 2 holds for the L 1 ([0, 1], C C C), that is for the periodic functions with period 1. In order to generalize this theorem to T -periodic functions L 1 ([0, T ], C C C) one has to consider the more general harmonic wavelet basis:
div.formula: ⎧ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎨ ⎪ ⎪ ⎪ ⎩ ϕ n k (x) def = 2 n/2 e T i (2 n x-k) -1 T i(2 n x -k) ,

The sparse representation can be further generalized to digital signals by using the Newland discrete transform [21].
